newsitem.title: ARGENTINA: Argentine bonds rise, client demand expected.
newsitem.headline: Argentine bonds rise, client demand expected.

text.p: Argentine bonds finished higher on Tuesday, driven by traders in anticipation of future client demand.
"There is a bullish mood at the moment," said a portfolio manager at a large Argentine bank. "Traders expect the client demand to come."

The dollar-denominated Bocon Previsional 2 due 2001 rose 0.30 to 122.30, while Argentina's FRB due 2005 advanced 3/8 to 87. However, traders reported very thin activity again, with still no signs of any pick-up in turnover imminent.
A trader said the market is "very solid" particularly thanks to the boost from the firm U.S. Treasury bond market. The yield on the 30-year Treasury bond last stood at 6.35 percent.
The portfolio manager said, however, he thought the market had risen too much recently and foreign clients would probably not be attracted at these price levels.
"I think the market is too expensive," he said.
In the money markets, call money rates fell to 6.75 percent from 6.85 percent.
